Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Growth of the Tibetan Plateau and Eastern Asia Climate: Clues to Understanding the Hydrological Cycle
Award.AbstractNarration:
For fifty years, the Tibetan Plateau has been recognized as the largest topographic feature that perturbs atmospheric circulation. It serves as an ideal field laboratory for understanding the geodynamic processes that build high terrain. Accordingly, the growth of the plateau should have altered atmospheric circulation and therefore written an evolving paleoclimatic signature not only on eastern Asian regional climates, but on global climate as well. Despite many recent studies, we still do not know precisely when the Tibetan Plateau reached its current dimensions and how it perturbs atmospheric circulation. This project brings together geodynamicists, atmospheric scientists, and paleoclimatologists in a multidisciplinary study of the when and the how.

One of the major goals of the project is to quantify the extent to which Tibet has grown by crustal thickening, by thrust faulting and folding, by flow within the crust that redistributes material there, or by replacement of cold mantle lithosphere with hotter material (all in a state of isostatic equilibrium). Such quantification will take big steps toward the understanding of how high plateaus are built and how continental lithosphere deforms, topics at the forefront of geodynamics.

Determining how Tibet has grown will require determining when crustal shortening and thickening occurred, using basic field methods and modern laboratory techniques, and quantifying paleoaltitudes with new isotopic tools. Applying such paleoaltimetric techniques, however, requires an understanding not only of how the atmosphere transports isotopes, but how the evolving high terrain affected surface temperatures at times in the past.

Overall goals: (i) to better constrain the history of the orography and geometry of Asia over the past ~50myr, (ii) to understand how this changing geometry has affected climate, (iii) and to help build an understanding of the interaction between climate and orography on geological time scales – in particular, how orography shapes climate by way of altering circulation and precipitation.

This project involves many PIs from institutions in the US and China. The larger goals germane to UW team are: (i) to illuminate the impact of plausible scenarios of topography and continental geometry of Asia on global climate and isotopic composition of precipitation over the past 50Myr; (ii) to compare these changes to those due to changes in greenhouse gases and orbital forcing over the past 50Myr; and (iii) to contribute to building a general understanding of the impact of orography and continental geometry on climate. The purpose of (i) and (ii) is to help inform the interpretation of the geological records (50Myr – present); the purpose of (iii) is to contribute to the understanding of the general circulation of the Earth’s atmosphere.

Key outcomes: First, insolation variations due to Earth’s orbital precession dominate over other geologic forcing factors on climate (temperature, precipitation, isotopic composition of climate). Extreme phases of precession fundamentally reengineer the dynamics of Earth’s monsoons in Africa, the Arabian peninsula, and the Levant. A second key finding is that the major orographic features on the planet today and for the past 50M yr have a profound impact on climate and the isotopic composition of precipitation local to the large orographic features – Tibet, the Andes, the Mongolian complex, and the North American Cordillera. With the exception of Mongolia, orography has a surprisingly small impact beyond the regional (local) scale -- less than that associated with year-to-year variability. Indeed, a third key result was that the Mongolian plateau has a greater impact on climate than the much larger Tibetan plateau; the Mongolian plateau is optimally located in relation to the atmospheric jet.

We have shown that, for the past ~50 million years, changes in orography and precession are the dominant factors that impact precipitation and the isotopic composition of precipitation in the Asian monsoon region, and in the tropics in general. Outside the tropics, changes in orography and the presence of ice sheets equally impact precipitation and the isotopic composition of precipitation; changes in orbital parameters and greenhouse gas concentration are of secondary importance.

Impact on science: Our results help interpret proxy data. For example, our work has re-shaped understanding of the isotopic record of calcite in stalagmites. Prior to our study, these records were widely interpreted as reflecting local precipitation. Our work has shown that except for special cases, these records mainly indicate changes in the pathways for water vapor and hence indicators of large scale climate.
